instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
hey there,

this board had a bit of corrosion after some cleanup was running fine. about a month later it unfortunately died, opened to inspect a hole in <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>. Now <SIGNAL>PP15V_T29</SIGNAL> is completely short to ground, i have removed almost every component but short is still there?

would it be safe to inject voltage into that line to see what gets hot?

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: No Title

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: Sounds like it is shorted possibly in layers of the board. You can inject voltage and see if you can find it. When you find it, TBT is not going to be useable ever again FYI.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: Is that because traces blown in the pcb? how much voltage to inject?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
i would remove <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U3890</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R0960</RESISTOR> be done with it. i think that should disable the <SIGNAL>PP15V_T29</SIGNAL> line

if you want to find the short then just start with from small until all the way up. no more than 15v obvious. I find pouring some alcohol will help, you still start to see smoke then poke it with a tweezer while wearing glove.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: Yeah I agree with Alan better solution

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Alan.L, post: 43338"]i would remove <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U3890</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R0960</RESISTOR> be done with it. i think that should disable the <SIGNAL>PP15V_T29</SIGNAL> line

if you want to find the short then just start with from small until all the way up. no more than 15v obvious. I find pouring some alcohol will help, you still start to see smoke then poke it with a tweezer while wearing glove.[/QUOTE]

thanks but after testing everything i found short where it blew. so its in the pcb layers, I scratched it back uv cured and short is gone. in this case is it best to still remove the parts you have mentioned? and im assuming <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> will need to be replaced on the board too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
You don't need <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> if thunderbolt area is damaged.
Also you can remove other chips form that area; can be reused in other repairs...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hey there, i removed <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U3890</CHIP> however i got nothing on <RESISTOR>R0960</RESISTOR>
I now dont have green light. ppbus is present as well as pp3v42

i will test other voltages and report back.

thanks for your help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_L</SIGNAL> 3.44v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 0v

<CHIP>U6900</CHIP>
p1: 3.49v
p4: 3.49v
p5: 3.49v

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>
p1: 3.33v
p2: 3.33v
p4: 3.49v
p5: 3.48v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0v"
PCH will not start power on sequence this way.
Are you using original 60W charger?
Try 85W charger too.
Also see if starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: no green light on 85w charger too - pch dead? possible to reflow around pch?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
Check continuity from <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> to the central pin of MagSafe connector.
Exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6900</CHIP> to mid pin of magsafe is all good - nothing low
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.56v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
"all good - nothing low"
I told you to check continuity on that line, not resistance to ground.
Do you get 3.3V at central pin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
what do you mean 3.3v at central pin? <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>?
j6900??

threads.message: I talk about MagSafe small board; or DCIN board, how you like to name it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: no chime...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
Do you get voltage on all big coils?
Any reaction at VCORE after 2-3s?
Can you confirm USB activity?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
missing voltage on L7550
L7510 L7520 have 0.9v

no usb activity

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
Do you get steady 0.9V from first moment, or the voltage drops from 1.1-1.2V.
L7550 is normal to have 0V with low charge on graphics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: it start from 1.12v then drop to 0.9v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
Seems that board works, if VCORE is adjusted.
Are you sure no USB activity?
Check that using OSX pendrive with Link LED; see if flashes, or not.
Disconnect internal HDD, to force USB booting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: Yes usb activity is there. the problem is i got no display and chime?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
PRAM reset done?
Did you test external video?
Disconnect internal LCD, just in case; also give it time to enter into OSX.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: PRAM didnt work. external is hard because now i got no thunderbolt. what is best way to get external?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
If you are 100% sure about USB activity, then post some voltages from LCD connector.
LCD screen need to be connected when measure there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message: i will post lcd voltage but how come no chime? is this because from audio lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with blown hole on <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>
threads.message:
ok so <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> not shooting out 3.3v but it does have input of 3.3v i check p1 and <SIGNAL>LCD_IGPWR</SIGNAL> missing i check resistor <RESISTOR>R1984</RESISTOR> it has no power and measures to around 81k

so i think pch is screwed.. i also run thermal and can see pch is very hot -like 75c normally i see around 50c

reflow pch?
